## Introduction

Previously, this course used John Nolt's *Logics* as its text book. While I still believe that the heavy emphasis on formal logic is important, the book itself did not provide enough informal support for the students to grasp the concepts in an intuitive manner. I discovered Peter @smit21's [*Logic Matters*](https://www.logicmatters.net/) towards the end of the semester. I recommeneded it to students as a supplementary reading and was pleased with the feedback and the improvement in their understanding. I am now relying on Smith's introductory text as the main text for this course, although I will contrast it with Nolt's more formal approach at various points.

### ðŸŽ¯ Learning Objectives

* Informal Logic
* Classical Propositional Logic syntax and semantics
* Natural Deduction Proofs for Propositional Logic
* Formalization Rules and General Propositions
* Predicate (Quantification Rules) Logic Semantics and Inference

This course will begins by looking at informal systems of logic. It then proceeds to classical propositional logic syntax, semantics and inference, then covering predicate logic semantics and inference. What is unique about this approach is that we begin with informal systems of logic and slowly proceed to formal systems of logic. We will then look at natural deduction proofs for propositional logic before looking at formalization rules and general propositions, and finishing out the term with quantification logic.
